job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Nashville, TN
pros: Extensive training! VUMC lives up to its reputation and is impressive on resume....you will be at the forefront of compassionate healthcare. Focus on getting as much experience and knowledge as you can during your employ there, and don't be too good to take a job in a for profit system when you are ready to move on.
cons: Collaborative work environment means you will have several level of supervisors and yearly reviews are tense. System growth is handicapped by academic budgeting process, severely limiting hiring and quality of care and leading to burn out. Accept a job offer once you get it, but have a plan to work there 18 months and then move on to a more sustainable (less stressful) work environment.

job_title: Mental Health Specialist II in Nashville, TN
pros: Pros: Looks good on resume Rewarding job if you like to help others You can switch shifts with people in order to take vacation
cons: Cons: Nurses run the world and think they know more about Psy than you do, even though you have the degree. They are in charge and you have no say in a patients care. Meant to be a starting job and they made that clear. No room to grow. High turn over from how poorly Mental Health Specialists are treated. You end up being a babysitter for the patients rather than taking the time to learn about them and counsel them in their situation. You will see very intense stuff, you have to have good work life balance. You are expected to lead mental health groups without ever getting training. Terrible pay, I wanted to presume a job that relates to my Psy degree, but making $12.50/hr and $14.50 with a masters... you can get a better job as a babysitter than that. MHS were constantly asked to take on another shift and making it a double of 16 hours of work. They got mad if I called out sick which I only did twice in the whole year I was there.

job_title: Revenue Cycle Manager in Nashville, TN
pros: Great Benefits like any full-time position these days.
cons: The culture needs some work. Leadership makes decisions without anticipating the impact it will have on its staff. Many Salaried employees end up working 50-60 hours a week without overtime as they are considered exempt. The additional hours stem from expanding services by acquiring hospitals or opening new clinics without hiring the support staff needed in Revenue Cycle to account for the additional volume of work. It has led to employees "burning out" and seeking employment elsewhere. There is so much red tape to request additional staff for your department that you won't hear back from leadership for a month or two. By the time you submit the request, your staff has already been working 50+ hour work weeks to only continue doing so until a decision is made. Definitely ask the department you are interviewing for to describe a typical work week so you can compare your yearly salary with the expected hours each week.

pros: Benefits (health, dental, 401K, etc)

Human Resources is a disaster, from the hiring process (months) to employee retention, they could care less about *you,* they only care about protecting themselves from being sued. Instead of working diligently to have excellent employees promoted, they prefer to protect bad employees with documented problems/issues that have no intention of doing better. The saying 'One bad apple ruins the bunch' applies here, yet VUMC will not dare get rid of the bad apple. Instead, they watch all other valued employees leave while protecting the problem employee. Your cries to HR will only infuriate you as they literally do not care. 

Salary is the other negative thing. They don't/won't pay, so the high turnover is real. More work and responsibility for less pay and lack of promotion.

pros:
Having worked at different psychiatric hospitals in the area, I can say that this one is the best overall. The benefits are great - they give you plenty of PTO, without having to earn it per hours worked like some places. The health insurance is a great price. Coworkers are great - lots of knowledgeable mental health specialists, and RNs who have a real interest in psychiatric nursing. Vanderbilt pays for your board certification testing, which is around $300-$400. It's typically pretty easy to get in touch with a doctor over the mobile heartbeat app, and they have an MD in-house 24/7. The social workers and pharmacists are good as well. Admissions and discharges are very easy compared to anywhere else I've worked. 
The parking situation is okay, you do have to park in the west garage and pay a fee, but it's only a 5 minute walk to VPH. The pay is fair, with raises 1-2x per year.
cons: One thing I've noticed is that staffing tends to be shotty, especially during 2nd shift. People leave and replacements are not found immediately, people call in sick and then it's short staffed. In either case you can't really predict that. Shift report takes a long time and you stay until everyone is done. There are some problems now and then with admissions coming up back to back during busy times (med pass).

review_title: Nightshift ER Is not for 30+year old nurses with experience
pros: Prestige in the company name. Thats literally all Ive got.
cons: Nightshift ER is clique-y and if you're not in your early 20s, single or unmarried, without children, and hitting the bar when you get off with the rest of them then you wont fit in. I'm an experienced ER nurse and Ive worked in most ERs in middle Tennessee and Northern Alabama. Ive never had a negative evaluation or even been called to an office until working there. The nurses with far less skill, knowledge, and experience had no issues if they were doing the above things and fit into that profile. If you have kids, a family, are older and experienced then you will not last long. They also tell everyone who hires in that you have to start on nights and you can go to days quickly....until youre off orientation and then youll realize the list to switch to days is nearly 2 years out, so get comfy with the vampire lifestyle if you want to keep the Vanderbilt title. The title is literally the ONLY good thing about working on their ER Night crew.

pros: Great experience if you are in nursing school or need hospital hours. Can learn an insane amount of skills that will give you a huge head start in clinicals and patient relations.
cons: This varies from floor to floor, but generally a care partner has 10-13 patients at a time. Sometimes more. Care Partners get all vital signs, help with ADLS, catheter insertions/care/removal, TONS of other tasks of that nature (you can do anything a nurse does except wound care, administer meds, and check blood sugar) and mostly toileting assists. Like I said, this varies from floor to floor depending on how independent and ambulatory your average patient is. It can be very stressful but can get you used to the fast-paced environment. Don’t let it discourage you from continuing your career!

review_title: I moved 2000 miles to work here
pros: On the cutting edge of multiple avenues - education, support and clinical care, supports patient centered care and nursing excellence; a Magnet designated facility who delivers excellence; fosters collaboration and provides opportunities with multidisciplinary partners for networking, limitless opportunities and resources for personal/professional growth and development through structured programs available to all employees; endless opportunities for nursing exploration and transitions; organization realizes that employees are their greatest asset and solicit feedback often regarding improvements on all levels; unparalleled expertise in education, research and clinical practice which benefits internal and external customers; organization is invested in employee health and well-being with robust programs to engage and encourage self-care. Vanderbilt has a large and growing walk-in clinic network that provides ready access to 7 day a week care and in convenient locations to homes and businesses. Management values active engagement of employees to help problem solve and improves processes in real time to improve patient experience and remove barriers that cause frustration or impair efficiency. I have never regretted the 2000 mile move for this career move!
cons: Large academic system which can be challenging for patients to navigate but also has apps which help direct patients to key patient areas.

Unempathetic management that are not interested in making changes for the better (although engagement is a continuous discussion. They haven't got a clue. 

No room for growth in some departments unless upper leadership tags you as a favorite. 
No desire to promote people because they are satisfied providing crushing/detrimental amounts of work on their staff. 
More concerned with numbers/metrics than the people that work for them.

review_title: It really depends on your manager...
pros: Benefits are good (but they used to be a lot better).  If you have a good manager, then you are blessed and you will likely want to stay at VUMC for many years.  On the whole, doctors, residents, NPs and nurses and support staff have the best working relationships I have ever experienced in my long career.
cons: The culture has changed drastically in the last 5 years.  The recent cutbacks were brutal and this affected culture and morale widely. So many bedside nurses left over the last 12-15 months that VUMC now has a nursing shortage.  Some units close beds to admissions because they don't have the necessary staff.  So now, staffing incentives are being offered to current staff to pick up additional shifts.

review_title: My overall experience was excellent.  I worked hard, got excellent reviews, and worked my way through graduate school.
pros: Amazing co-workers and good benefits.  The tuition assistance program was the best benefit for me.  I left and took a job making twice the pay I would have if I remained at Vanderbilt.
cons:
You have to pay to park at work.  There's no excuse for that.  If you park in the wrong place you are fined $100.  If you don't pay, your car is booted.  Vanderbilt was the lowest paying hospital in Nashville and benefits were being cut rapidly before I left, including the tuition benefit.  Unit managers were quitting in droves around 2011-2013 and high profile physicians were being unceremoniously shown the door.  

The bottom line is that this is an extremely wealthy university/medical center that has allowed an enormous disconnect to develop between the workers and those in power.

review_title: A dream job crushed by an ex-military manager with an iron fist.
pros: The benefits are awesome! The pay was above average for the type of position. You definitely feel a sense of pride when you tell people you work at Vandy (even if they do automatically assume you're a nurse). The chances for advancement within your department can vary. However, throughout the hospital, your choices are numerous.
cons:
Strictly speaking from the Materials Support departments standpoint, the phrase "You can take the man out of the Army, but you can't take the Army out of the man" rings true. To go from a Manager that embodied everything an employee would need and want (highly competent, team-centered communicator, and a positive personality) to a Manager that would go on vacation and only tell upper management, holds semiannual staff meetings (whereas their predecessor held them monthly) and sees everything in black and white, was a shock. I, and several others within the department, went through a period of grieving when we realized that our "close knit working family" was no more.
Again, each department has its own unique dynamics. Some folks thrive more under certain managerial styles than others.

pros:
[This is a huge institution and lots of variability] Environment is generally laid back. I have lots of flexibility with my schedule.

In medical research at Vanderbilt, you will be surrounded by intelligent people.
cons:
One universal problem is that there is a very strong divide between faculty and staff. As a staff member in research, no matter how educated, knowledgeable, valuable, hard-working, skilled, etc, you are, you will always be below the lowest faculty member in many ways. Additionally, at least on the research side, there are many positions that are staff, but in actuality, their job description and actual work more closely resembles those of faculty. 

Things have deteriorated so much over the last 5-10 years. We never get to go to conferences anymore, and the criteria for promotion has changed drastically (although this is not overtly acknowledged). I have grown more and more unhappy over the years, and I can't wait to find a new job.

Vanderbilt has been decreasing benefits more and more over the years. Salaries are low. They laid of thousands of people around 2013. They have a new "Pod" system that organizes departments, and the Pod managers have put more and more unncecessary restrictions on our members, for example, restricting working from home when there had been no problems.

review_title: This is a great place to work.
pros:
I am a nurse in an hourly position and I truly feel the management team in place is paramount. They encourage and support efforts to continue my education. The scheduling system is fair, it isn't left up to one person to decide everyone's schedule like my previous employer.
      I am extremely satisfied with my work environment. They do not tolerate disrespect to their nurses from anyone (attendings, residents, other nurses). At my previous employer the doctors had free reign to act inappropriately, and nurses were shown zero respect as professional members of the team. It is a very professional environment.
      I should also mention I received a significant pay increase when I started at Vanderbilt and have received several in the last 3 years. I came from an institution that never provided increases. I was there for 4 years and they would tell their nurses year after year there was no money while they installed HD flat screens in all the rooms. When things got tight at Vanderbilt there was none of this.
cons: Parking is definitely an issue. While most University hospitals do charge their employees to park, I do agree it is ridiculous. If you work day shift expect to spend 20-30 minutes to get from your car to your unit. Night shift doesnt have this problem.

review_title: Great people, working environment, and benefits, but not very competitive pay
pros: The environment here for research is for the most part very collaborative and pleasant. There are of course exceptions, but I've run into very few of them. It's also possible to seamlessly collaborate with other institutions. Vanderbilt has no problem with open source software, which is a big pro for me. Being a hospital, the health benefits are top notch for the price we pay. The vacation and sick time seems generous as well and carries over across years.
cons: The pay is no longer competitive for my experience level and work. It was when I started here, fresh out of college, but it hasn't risen fast enough as I've gained experience. Also, the tuition benefit is annoying. It pays 70% of the tuition for 3 credit hours per semester, which means getting a part-time degree takes a long time or gets to be very expensive.

job_title: IT Project Manager in Nashville, TN
pros: They give a good amount of PTO at the beginning of each fiscal year. You cannot roll any over, but I believe they provide plenty for me to take a few vacations and time off for kids breaks. School reimbursement is a great perk as well, however I am grandfathered in for the better percentage rate. It has decreased for folks new to the company.
cons: Pay is severely under the norm. Even if you advance to a higher position you will only get pennies from HR for the salary quote. Only way to increase a significant amount is to leave and come back. That does not make business sense at all. This is the main reason after 9 years that I am looking for my next career growth opportunity outside of this organization.

pros: Once you are trained, you move fluidly into being part of the machine.  If you mind your Ps and Qs, nobody bothers you, you just clock in, do your best, and clock out.  Once you are ingrained, if you play well with others, it is not difficult to keep your job.  If you are someone who does not want to answer to deadlines or your boss every day, this job is for you.  The flexibility with scheduling is better than anywhere I have ever worked before.  The healthcare benefits are great, especially if you stay within the Vanderbilt network.
cons: Long, long hours sitting. A twelve hour shift in one place with only a quick 30 minute break and two quick 10 minute breaks (if you are lucky enough to get them every day) can wear you down after a while.  Training your brain to multitask causes some form of adult ADD.  No raises for the past two years, supposedly due to the economy and "restructuring of the work flow".  Company culture is preached but not exemplified often enough.

review_title: Decent place if you don’t mind being micromanaged
pros: PTO is given to you very July to use throughout the year, no waiting to accrue if you need to take time off. Name recognition (who hasn’t heard of Vanderbilt). Looks good on a resume. Decent pay for the position I was in.
cons: PTO is also a con in that you draw ALL time off from it (vacation, sick time and holiday pay). Pay to park and then a long walk to your work area. Shuttles are available but are often full and running behind. Managers and leadership claim they want to help you be successful but lack follow through. Will often scrutinize your work even after you’ve alerted them to situations that affect your work. Doctors can be difficult to deal with and will often smile to your face and then walk down the hall and throw you under the bus to your manager. Teammates (and I use that term loosely) gossip about everyone. Low morale, high turnover and just a toxic place to work.

pros: Vandy has flexible hours in most departments. RNs & many areas set their own schedules and I actually had the opportunity to work from home. There are great discounts to community events. It may sound weird but a lot of people respect you when you say "I work at Vanderbilt".
cons: Not the same company from years ago. A shift around 2007-2009 changed the company culture, maybe it was Gordon Gee's departure. Things changed and management (housewide) made the "bottom line" the only factor. Employee morale is wayyy down and it is sad to see such a great institution with a great name change so drastically. Many benefits were reduced, cut, and annual bonuses are non-existent.

review_title: Okay place for a pharmacist to work considering today's healthcare climate.
pros: Chances for advancement, good compensation, learning atmosphere, many different types of pharmacist jobs and opportunity, tuition benefit for employee and children
cons: Hospital system is cutting back on employees making for a stressful working environment both from a job security and workload standpoint.  Poor management in an area leads to poor morale.  Poor communication and high technician turnover in my area.  Poor leadership with a "moving target" philosophy on direction.  Very large hospital system makes an individual little more than a number, i.e., everyone is quickly replaceable.

pros: Benefits, hours, no weekends, free parking.
cons: Like going back to junior high school. Mean girls' clique who bully, spread rumors,  sabatoge, withold information relevant to your job & policy changes, and lie to your face. Don't trust anyone, don't share personal info, don't report it or your life will become a living H_ll, due to the retaliation. Keep your head down and brown nose or you'll be singled out, bullied, and harassed daily by the clique until you quit or they change policies to set you up and put you on corrective action and terminate you! Stay away, unless you were a mean girl in school then you'll fit right in.  This was one of the most toxic environments I have ever worked in.  Run away as fast as you can!!

review_title: Thriving and competitive place to work
job_title: Research Assistant Professor in Nashville, TN
pros:
Cutting edge research. 

Very good institutional support for personal growth (e.g. career guidance, grant writing, research support for pilot studies, mentorship, workshops and studios)

World-class informatics infrastructure in support of research
cons:
Financial woes (not specific to this place): as an academic medical center it has endured its share of science funding squeeze and other healthcare related financial stress.

In my field, the salaries are not competitive with the market making hiring and retention of support and technical staff very difficult.

Recent austerity measures have left a bad mark on staff morale. If it continues long term, it may damage the reputation of the place as a desirable work location and lead to an irreversible brain drain.

review_title: Great Benefits which outweigh the negatives
pros: My manager is amazing. Super flexible, understanding, and actively asks if you're engaged and satisfied with the work that you do. It's a family type atmosphere and my department is genuinely interested in each others lives. The tuition benefits are exceptional. 70% of tuition paid for children. 70% of tuition paid for employees. I've gotten a Master's Degree for almost free.
cons: The pay is majorly below the market average, like 25% below what you would be making if you worked for a for profit company. However the vacation (almost 6 weeks) is awesome, opportunities to work from home, and encouragement of work life balance make up for it. It is a tough time right now with a lot of restructuring and lack of communication. The new normal is to do more with less resources.

review_title: My experience at Vanderbilt Medical Center is similar to my star rating. Wasn’t bad wasn’t amazing
job_title: Research Assistant II in Nashville, TN
pros: I enjoyed being in an atmosphere with so many medical professionals. There are lots of opportunities to learn new things and hear interesting speakers. Vanderbilt also has a nice benefits packages including reduced tuition for employees and their children.
cons: It’s difficult to move up pay wise. I came in with little experience so started on the low end of the pay scale. Once you accept at the low end it’s very difficult to break out. I have been here for 4 years and my pay has increased by $2/hr. If my husband didn’t also work it would be difficult to sustain life in Nashville as 1/2 my salary goes to childcare.

job_title: Talent Acquisition Consultant in Nashville, TN
pros: Educational Assistance.  Vanderbilt helps pay for some certifications.  High turnover in some departments can lead to advancement opportunities for others. Health benefits are decent but they could be better for spouses.  Most Vanderbilt employees are friendly.
cons: Leadership can be inexperienced.  Pay is meager and education is not taken into account.  Pay increases are non existent.  Performance Management works off of IOU's and "Atta Boy's" since there are no pay increases.  Work - Life balance is not what it should be.  PTO is being cut subsequent years in a row.

pros: Insurance is pretty good but you have to go to Vanderbilt doctors.  If you want to go to another doctor insurance pays almost nothing.
cons: No opportunity.  Very low pay. Very low raises IF you even get one.  If you have problems with a supervisor don't bother trying to go to HR.  They always side with the supervisor.  Head of HR is the worst.  You have to pay to park and there is never enough parking.  They always talk about how tight money is but there are many people who make over 1 million a year.  Old outdated systems and equipment.  They will spend tons of money only on executives who make tons of money and then say they don't have the money to give raises.  Employees are overworked because they will not staff appropriately saying they can't afford to  hire more people but then give executives huge raises when staff can't even get raises.  They almost never promote from within and you really do have to know someone to move to another job.

review_title: Your experience depends on your department
pros: Good medical benefits, lifestyle convenience (medical care in the same area as work), lifestyle benefits (free on-campus gyms, valet services, etc.).
cons: Vanderbilt is known around town for paying much less than most businesses/hospitals.  Employee parking is expensive and inconvenient (most employees have to park in very distant lots, requiring a shuttle ride into campus).

review_title: Not what you would expect from Vanderbilt
job_title: Senior Talent Consultant in Nashville, TN
pros:
My particular position pays fairly well compared to other positions in the organization.
Flexibility in hours and can work from home after being in position for 6 months.
cons:
Your work is never enough.
All recruiters have too heavy of workloads to be efficient. 
Vanderbilt is not competitive in pay so it makes it difficult to recruit.
Everyone in the talent department is spread thin so there is not much support from upper management.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Nashville, TN
pros: Benefits themselves aren't bad; great networking opportunities if you pursue them; ability to work with amazingly talented physicians, professionals, etc.  If you have experience, your salary is meant to be calculated on your relevant experience- not necessarily your job title.
cons:
Salary- if you have a position the only way to really move up in ranking is to "reclassify" your position (for example a Coordinator I to a Coordinator II).  HR is strict on reclassifying employees and you essentially have to prove that you've already been doing the position you are reclassifying for.
The other way is to apply for a completing different position within VUMC (new department, boss, etc.).

job_title: Research Assistant Professor in Nashville, TN
pros: Cutting edge research; supportive, collaborative environment; tons of research resources; the best place to do biomedical and biotech research in Nashville (and one of the best in the Southeast)
cons: Academic research is a very challenging field; Vanderbilt as an institution has little loyalty to researchers or research staff - if they don't bring in their own funding, they don't get paid; research perspectives are driven by the medical center's very traditional medical-centric vision; traditional academic research is going to change immeasurably in the next 5-10 years; huge pay gaps between basic science (PhD) researchers and clinical (MD) researchers - this seems universal, but a challenge, nonetheless.

review_title: Low pay, bad benefits, limited communication from management, no raises
pros: My direct manager is invested in my professional development.
cons: very very low pay especially for administrative positions, no raises, benefits continue to be taken away from all VUMC employees, you have to pay to park at work, bully breading ground - managers turn their eyes to it, senior managers are disconnected from reality, very limited communication on policies and roll out procedures, due to layoffs and other changes the workload has drastically increased, Senior managers are training lower managers to sugar coat all bad changes and it makes employees feel like they can't say anything negative out of fear of retaliation. As soon as you think they've stopped taking from you, watch out... they'll take more. And don't forget to smile while they're hurting you, or you'll get talked down to.

review_title: Stay away from Patient Access Services; On-Campus Work Experience Is Much, Much Better
pros: Health insurance and other benefit costs are very good; the hospital provides excellent medical care.  Many on campus departments are highly rewarding and have positive environments.
cons: The organization is absolutely huge and bureaucratic.  It is easy to get lost in the shuffle.  The Patient Access Services area is badly mismanaged and in some instances openly hostile to employees (it is not unheard of to be screamed at by a senior leader), however, due to its offsite location, leadership continues to be able to survive.  The true turnover for that area tells the story but the organization fails to deal with the problem.  On campus departments are much better for employees and are recommended.

review_title: I research and analyze data to deduce protein signaling networks
pros: The lab is very friendly and relaxed.  There are plenty of opportunities to attend lectures and conferences that have the leading researchers in the field.  HR makes a great effort to make sure the entire University is connected and educated about future directions.  HR also does a great job of having social activities for different groups of workers.
cons: It can be strenuous when one has to present results within a time frame that is not conducive for the research.  Furthermore, promotions and tenure can be difficult to achieve.

pros: Brand Recognition, Social Health Involvement
cons: Enterprise is silo and position protection oriented. No focus on associates. No career path, Pay scale under market. No security.

review_title: Very disappointed in the leadership, management, culture, and values of Vanderbilt University Medical Center.

The Vanderbilt name is associated with prestige and high accomplishments.
Salaries and benefits are competitive.
cons: The leadership and management do not value their employees and create an environment of fear, intimidation and bullying to get the results they desire. I witnessed a great deal of corruption and poor judgement, as well as ill-treatment of loyal hard-working employees.

review_title: Good for newbies, but go elsewhere to find a home.

review_title: Mental Health Specialist? More like do everything and get no credit for it.
job_title: Mental Health Specialist in Nashville, TN
pros: I can put Vanderbilt Medical Center on my resume.
cons: For a four year degree in psychology you get $12 and with a masters you get $14. This is ridiculous for the amount of work and trauma that comes out of this job. This job was mentally and emotionally draining. You are not respected or cared about unless you are a nurse who knows nothing about mental health and gets over $40,000 a year.  Mental Health Specialists are pretty much sitters for the unit and run around doing favors. You will do the hardest work and get the least amount of money. You will interact with the patients all day and have the best knowledge, but no one will hear you out. Management was also terrible because all unit leaders can only be nurses.

review_title: Great Potential Place to Work, but needs some changes
job_title: Senior Software Developer in Nashville, TN
pros: Great coworkers.  Agile Methodologies being used and constantly improving.  Training every year is provided.  Flexible schedules. Tuition Benefit for children.
cons: Only 3 raises in last 7 years.  Bonuses are very rare.  Same raise is given to all employees regardless of how hard you work and how productive you are.  Working Remote full-time is not what management prefers.  Management has decided to spend the majority of money buying and integrating, rather than developing new software.

pros:
You get to pay to park! Your other choice is to walk about 2 miles to your car or park nearby and have your car booted! So you can work for below market salary! 
But the education benefit is so good...if you don't get 'laid off' before you get to use it!
cons:
Poor leadership; some supervisors actually PROMOTE problem employees to get them out of their area (Linda, I'm looking at you!). They will lie to you and twist words so you will stay with no salary increases for YEARS! (Hang in there; we are a family; hard times will pass! We will take care of you!) 
Then they bring in the axe man and you are gone....but hang in there! There will be jobs for you!

The best part of it all is that they didn't include HR in at least some of the layoffs. Ridiculous!

pros: The work is largely self-paced, and the hours are very flexible. All in all, not a difficult job, just a tedious one. Earphones are allowed and, in my opinion, are necessary!
cons: The supervisor will constantly micro-manage you, and often struggles to respond to questions despite the fact that she has supposedly been doing this job for many years. In addition, they have a strict policy that NO other work can be done at the desk, despite the fact that this results in many periods of time where there is literally nothing else to do than watch papers feed through a scanner.

review_title: Research Assistant II; good research exposure for bare minimum pay
job_title: Research Assistant II in Nashville, TN
pros: research 1 institute and endless opportunities to learn from the best in the field. The atmosphere is usually inviting and people are not afraid to voice political views (this can be con as well since it can be a bit irksome at times).
cons: employee retention is not valued.  Only tenured professors and MD are safe from layoffs. There are no employer/supervisor evaluations, only employee evaluations which allows lopsided reviews of workplace efficiency.

review_title: An expensive place to work, benefits reduced every year, lay-offs of non-faculty every year
job_title: Research Coordinator III in Nashville, TN

review_title: Work here if you want to be treated like a robot!
job_title: Administrative Assistant I in Nashville, TN

cons: doing task that are far out of your job description, lack of proper training, no raises, high benefits that won't cover anything, lots of incompetent managers & directors who are rude and arrogant, payment for parking each month that's taken out of your check, unhelpful and careless HR department... the list could go on. I'm not bitter, just stating facts. Vanderbilt can improve on a lot.

job_title: Nutrition Assistant/Dietary Clerk in Nashville, TN

You have pay to park. If you get sick our have a family emergency itll cout against you. A doctors note excusing you for xxx amount of days still leave you with a. Couple accurance. review_title: I have been very happy with the postdoctoral training system at Vanderbilt in spite of mediocre direct mentorship.

Collegial working atmosphere
