review_title: Recent changes making Vandy less appealing among Nashville medical Centers
pros: Wonderful co-workers in my department
cons:
Parking is a nightmare
Poor middle management
Took away vacation accrual to prevent layoffs,which saved 50 million dollars, saying during in Vandy'smentire history they had never had to lay off a single employee
5 weeks later laid off 300
"VANDY WAY" is cost cutting and does not have the patients' best interest at heart
Highest infection rate of all of Nashville's medical centers
Wastes money to relocate new employees instead of employee retention 
Does not utilize cost saving measures recommended by nursing staff
Management refuses to cut their multimillion dollar salaries, bonuses, and vacation time
Took away education benefits

pros: Vandy keep the nurse patient ratios at a manageable level. The teamwork on my unit was excellent. Self-scheduling is also a plus.
cons: The pay is not super high. Things that would help with patient satisfaction were not always available (i.e. cots, soda, jello). It seems like management doesn't really care about nurse retention. Unless you are going to grad school or you have kids that are going to college, there really isn't an incentive to stay.

pros: Nice facility at One Hundred Oaks Mall. Rehabilitated the neighborhood.
cons: There are two PhD in the department. The one has no true experience but is capable of talking its way through anything. The people who hired it do not know anything about genetics. It advised them how to set up the department and later could not use 12 million dollars worth of equipment ordered. The second that was hired knows its field. The two are struggling over the control of the office and actually give different answers for the patient depending upon which is assigned the task the particular week. In one department, a patient can receive two different answers.

pros: I have worked in two different departments within the Medical Center. From talking with peers across departments, I can tell you that your experience is greatly determined by the department and who your supervisor is. I love the work I'm currently doing and feel very supported by my colleagues and supervisor. But a friend of mine who works in the same department but on a different team is miserable because she has a boss who doesn't respect boundaries and co-workers who don't pull their weight.
cons: Annual raises are not guaranteed and are typically very low (2%, maybe 3% if you're lucky.)

review_title: Hiring process needs a serious overhaul.
job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Nashville, TN
pros: Great benefits. That’s about it.
cons: Hiring process takes entirely too long whether you’re an internal or an external candidate.  Have to wait and wait for an HR drone to contact you ... if they even do. I had to chase one down for days.  Hiring managers tell you nothing. The system needs a SERIOUS overhaul and HR needs to communicate accurate, timely, truthful information to  candidates.

review_title: Great To Say You Work at Vanderbilt, Not So Great to Actually Work There
job_title: Health Information Systems Project Manager I in Nashville, TN
pros: It's Vanderbilt!  If you can get in before the College Tuition Benefit is completely eliminated, AND you can continue working there until you child graduates college, you're going to save a bunch of money.
cons: This is an organization in complete disarray, with a startlingly-widespread lack of leadership in all areas.  Morale is at an all-time low, and with all the restructuring, no one knows if they'll still have a job 6 months from now.

review_title: Excellent culture and values. Not so much work/life balance.
job_title: Lead Supply Technician in London, England
pros: Excellent benefits. Professional and accepting work place. Flexible when needed. Many opportunities to move up. Lots of none monetary perks and bonus. An open minded atmosphere that allows for others to speak out if issues or problems are found. Overtime is always available if wanted.
cons: Ineffective staff are difficult to punish or remove if problems are persistent. Work flow issues can be difficult to resolve because of Vanderbilt's massive size. Implementing change can be a long drawn out process they may ultimately not lead to any resolution. High turnover rates lead to constant shortages that in turn cause existing staff have to cover making it difficult to schedule personal appointments and time.

review_title: Great career development opportunities (BRET office). Personal mentoring/guidance in the lab setting needs improvement.
pros: Good for temporary employment as a scientist; Opportunities for career development from: BRET office of Career Development, VICTR, and Center for Teaching are excellent, but you must be proactive and self-motivated to pursue these opportunities; Flexible working hours (depends on your PI/mentor); Safe and beautiful location in Nashville; Affordable living
cons: Salary and Benefits (expected with a temporary position); Elitist attitudes (primarily from students who commonly view state-educated individuals and Southerners as inferior); Principal Investigators (PI/mentors) often too busy to provide personal guidance (but this is common in research); Work is undervalued; Lacking opportunities for career advancement so this job is stepping stone to the next company

pros: large, great opportunity for advancement. work with some brilliant people
cons: Because its so large, there is a big bureaucracy and can be difficult to get things done.  Morale is low and top management can't seem to get it. Changing the time off system to a PTO system has been a disaster and has lead to large employee unrest. Turnover is high. Management is aware, but can't seem to wrap its mind around what to do.

pros: The people are incredibly nice, and on the Research end of things the projects are very interesting and provide a great deal of knowledge. Also, for those students looking to learn technical skills, this is a great place to learn them.
cons: I would say that there really aren't any downsides from my experience. If you are working in the medical center but are a Temp employee then you have to get your hours sheets from the main office which is really far away instead of medical payroll.

job_title: Research Assistant II in Nashville, TN
pros: Organization and Work Environment is generally very healthy and people oriented.
cons: My research position was very boring and didn't keep me as engaged as I would have liked. As a pre-med about to apply to medical school, I recommend that if you are planning on moving on to graduate or professional school you have to be very careful which labs you work in. Otherwise you will not get your name on publications.

pros: Lots of area discounts, the ability to work in a collaborative atmosphere, amazing science. Core facilities are a great resource. Nashville is a great place to live, and graduate student stipends go far here.
cons: None, really.  It's a great graduate program and Vanderbilt's reputation will help when you're ready to move on. Lots of grad students tend to stay on once they've defended, so it might be hard for someone outside of Vanderbilt to get a post-doc position.  Lots of the faculty and drs. also went to school here--kind of neat and obviously they liked Vanderbilt enough to stay, but it can also seem a bit cliquish.

review_title: After 17 years, I just resigned this week. Senior leadership don't care about long term employees.
job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Nashville, TN
pros: Other than having some really great co-workers, there aren't a lot of Pros.
cons: Too many in senior management who don't possess the necessary people skills to manage.

job_title: Data Management Specialist in Nashville, TN
pros: Amazing colleagues and mentors.  I have never worked for another organization or team that cares so much about learning and developing their employees. It was an embarrassment of riches when it came to mentors and leadership standards and well as culture of caring about the job and adding value to a community.  Additionally, it is great that there are no forced holidays. If you want to save up your vacation time and not use it during labor day, or thanks giving but save it for a different day, you are able to do so.
cons: Low pay compared to other companies in the industry.

review_title: $13.94 per hour as an office manager overseeing clinical and research budgets, managing scheduling and office staff.
job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Nashville, TN
pros:
Top quality medical center with may opportunities to learn.  The Children's Hospital is beautiful and if you want to get outside during your break or at lunch the main campus lawns are only a couple minutes walk and it can really calm a stressful day. 

Benefits are affordable if you use a VUMC doctor, you will received a copay discount. There is also an employee appointment line where you call and be put at the first available appointment or even worked into a physicians schedule.  This helps when you are really sick and need to be treated.  They also have an emplyee clinic for acute care.
cons:
Parking is annoying.  You will have to pay to park and they will take the money directly from your paycheck.  Depending where you park depends how much it will cost.  I parked in the 25th Avenue Garage and it cost me $10.40 to park on the roof.  There is cheaper parking in the shuttle lot. Either way there are always shuttles to avoid the rain or you can always walk.

Not many affordable lunch options unless you go to the Children's Hospital. They have Taco Bell, Subway, Ben & Jerrys and a cafeteria.  These places cost a little more than if you were to go outside of the campus but it is convenient.  Be prepared to pay with cash if you are going to eat at Taco Bell. The main hospital cafeteria is overpriced in my opinion.  Salads are wieghed and a side salad could cost you $5.00.  I you want a salad as a meal then you may pay $7-10.  Best bet, take you lunch or walk to somewhere off campus.

pros: VUMC has exciting research going on around every corner.  This is fun to learn about and everyone has an opportunity to participate in some way if they want.
cons: The whole structure is changing and while the administration talks a lot about communication, there seems to be very little reliable information about the changes and when they will be happening (until after they happen).

review_title: It's a great place to work if you are a Doctor or Researcher
job_title: Technical Support Specialist in Nashville, TN
pros: Vanderbilt University and the Medical Center are recognized across the country.
cons: Very poor communication from some members of middle and some senior management.  Not always consistent policy or the way policy is applied.

review_title: Times are changing in the Health Care Profession.
job_title: Mid Level Manager in Nashville, TN
pros: Steady pay check, better than average benefits.
cons: Due to reductions in Health Care reimbursements and Federal budget reductions, we have gone two years without a pay raise. Our paid time off benefits are also being reduced.

job_title: Quality Assurance Analyst in Nashville, TN
pros: Paid vacation, work from home, intelligent / capable peers, paid continuing education training opportunities annually.
cons: There's no bonus structure set up for employees (engineers/QA) for hitting targets or achieving success that goes above and beyond the work delivered. It is VERY difficult to move in to a position who's title is outside your current role. For example, if you were currently a QA Engineer and you set a career goal to achieve a Software Engineer title that's outside the QA scope.

pros: Good department leadership and team work
cons: System not employee friendly. Retention is a goal for every employee but it is top managements responsibility to make the work conditions better. Low pay.

job_title: IT Project Manager in Nashville, TN
pros: You will be stretched to organize and prioritize your work independently and learn to juggle ever changing timelines and expectations. You will receive excellent peer support and advocacy from leadership.
cons: Vanderbilt has a well respected name, but that doesn't mean it's a well oiled machine. Be prepared to step into great work, but to constantly be untangling some chaos.

review_title: Low pay, Better than thou doctors
job_title: Central Appointment Scheduler in Nashville, TN
pros:
Meet a lot of great people just was not impressed with management. I learned how I did not want to treat my employees. 
Tuition Reimbursement is great, yet not sure how much longer this will be around.
cons:
Expects you to give a 150% but fail to give a raise, praise, or promotion. 
Paying to park was ridiculous. Parking fees should be related to income.

review_title: Centralization in process - dismissal of long term employees
pros: The benefits are great and the general atmosphere is pleasant.
cons: Depending on your department you could find yourself being dismissed at no fault of your own under the guise of saving money. Department by department things can vary, but in general there is an atmosphere of fear and trepidation at the new policies set in motion after the new Dean was put in place.

review_title: I love testing unique in house developed applications
job_title: Senior QA Analyst in Nashville, TN
pros: Great people encouraged personal growth development of all the places I have worked this one makes you have pride in what you have worked on it is great when you hear how users love to use a program that you helped get into production makes all the work worth it
cons: Tend to be silos there are several different development groups and sometimes it seems like there might be several groups working on the same product but for different clinics communication can be challenging as well sometimes you can feel like you aren't being heard or that your opinion isn't important

pros: My patients and Providers. Also my team. The ones that I work with day after day with, we just have this way of knowing exactly who and what  is  needing to be done next.
cons: Their are a few but not enough to bother with.

review_title: Excellent education opportunities, lowest paying hospital for nurses (facility face lift needed)
pros: Educational Opportunities- Vanderbilt offers to pay for your school tuition (12 hours per year at any institution) and pays for 70% of your children's tuition for 4 years at any institution. Also good health insurance and 401 K matching.
cons:
LOWEST paying hospital in Nashville!!!!!!!
So big that it is easy to lost in the bureaucracy of it all.  
Incompetent Managers at all levels in the hospital. 
Out of date facilities and equipment for nurses.

review_title: A great place to work, with excellent people
job_title: IT Project Manager in Nashville, TN
pros: Work/Life balance is obviously important to management.  I am able to maintain a healthy professional AND personal life while working at Vanderbilt.  Having young children, this is especially important to me (the onsite day care is a great help).  Additionally, the benefits are better than those of comparable employers.
cons: Just like an ocean liner or an iceberg, VUMC does not change directions swiftly.  Changes come about in very small gradual movements.  Navigating the red-tape and political landscape can be frustrating at times.

review_title: Amazing Oncology Floor, Manager and Coworkers amazing. Hospital doesnt care about staff
pros: Lots of education opportunities and growth. Able to treat complicated patients and cases from all around the South, Well respected hospital. Great coworkers and management. New floor (critical care tower)
cons: Horrendous pay... Bottom 10% that nurses make in the entire nation. Haven given a raise in over 3 years, Have taken away holiday gifts, No long accrual sick or vacation pay and cannot cash out when leaving the hospital. Nursing patient rations increasing. Very short staff and making no improvements towards hiring staff

review_title: Cried when I had to leave
job_title: Obstetrics Registered Nurse in Nashville, TN
pros: I experienced a great work environment with diverse patient population. The unit I worked on had excellent management and intelligent, hardworking nurses and nursing assistants. I only left because I was moving. Otherwise, I would have stayed forever. My coworkers were kind and always willing to help in anyway possible. I highly recommend working here.
cons: The patients are usually higher risk patients which can lead to a high stress work load at times.

review_title: Good labs, great people, good environment
pros: There is a plethora of labs to choose from. Many of which are pretty good, but even fewer are really great. There are lots of other benefits that come with being at Vanderbilt University outside of the science.
cons: There's not much to say that is really bad about the place. I enjoyed my time there. I don't like how slow the science is, but I think this is something inherit in academia.

review_title: Inconsistent policies, inadequate management, and very poor quality internal systems
pros: At the current point in time, none.
cons:
1. This company has a terrible internal culture.  
2. Massive inconsistencies in policy.  The company has flipped from offering flexibility in work schedules to completely inflexible schedules.  Believe me, there is no room for "life to happen", lest you get fired. Long-term employee satisfaction include culture and values, career opportunities, and trust in senior leadership. It's not happening at Vanderbilt.
3. Arrogant management with few skills incapable of setting realistic goals, incapable of "steering the ship".
4. Extremely inefficient computer system. This costs companies in productivity, revenue, training and even the customer experience.  
5. Mass exodus of employees to include numerous physicians.

pros:
Good place to learn and get direct patient care experience especially if you're pursuing nursing as a a career. Can't advance or get a promotion unless you have RN or another advanved degree. 
 More/less autonomy depending on the unit you work in. Okay benefits package
cons: Lowest paying hospital in Nashville area, employees pay for parking, some nurses pass off extra work to care partners that they don't want to do, little to no raise each year, almost always understaffed no matter where you work

review_title: Lots of changes happening, not all are good
pros:
Collegial environment
Forward thinking
Good benefit coverage and some unique ones 
Flexible schedules possible
cons:
Very political 
More and more layers of management
High amount of uncertainty with regard to job security
Newest benefits for new year more expensive 
Parking is a nightmare
Very little room to grow in your career path, if it even exists

job_title: Lead Technical Specialist in Nashville, TN
pros: The name used to mean something good on a resume.  Some of the people really do care about their colleagues.
cons: Vanderbilt used to be a great place to work.  It was a culture of caring for patients and employees.  Now it is about the bottom line and only the bottom line.  If to an anonymous accountant somewhere you make too much money (after years of lower than median pay for your job), then Senior management wants you gone ASAP.  Vanderbilt has been "facing headwinds" for years and has been cutting staff, over working the remaining staff, cutting pay by not giving raises for 5 years, cutting vacation time, reducing benefits, and outsourcing their talent to other companies to try to make up for these oft mentioned "headwinds."   So while they have a 5 billion dollar endowment, they choose to make the people caring for you in the hospital balance on their financial backs the short comings of the Leadership by taking away the financial incentive for that care. Quality of care will decline if the people caring for you are worried if they will have a job tomorrow, since they just saw half of their colleagues get cut/outsourced.  Middle management is rarely listened to and Senior Leadership is a top down command and control system that brokers no dissidents.  The pay for performance rating is a joke.  There have been no raises for the workers in 5 years and even when they did give a token raise it was limited by the Senior Leadership.  Leadership gives the marching orders of how many people will get raises at any given rating in a department and then your review is lowered to match those numbers, often by a manager that never knows what you do on a day to day basis.

pros: Vanderbilt offers great pay, wonderful benefits, and upward mobility no matter how low on the ladder your position may be.   Supervisors frequently encourage you to learn new skills, and in-office training sessions are readily available.  There's also a fair amount of pride at working in such a prestigious organization.  The courtyards are also beautiful.
cons: VUMC attracts many Type-A employees and managers who are sticklers for perfection.  The work-life balance can sometimes be difficult due to the heavy workload.

pros: Pretty flexible work schedule. Ability to shadow/observe most any position to grow professionally and/or learn about complimentary or related departments and positions to better your own performance. Opportunity to audit graduate classes free of charge. Free vaccines. Lastly, the clinical staff here are tremendous... the efforts that they go to to deliver top-notch care is unbelievable. Change happens so rapidly at institutions of this size and across the healthcare landscape, and these clinicians adapt so well. I admire these outstanding clinicians for the incredible services and outcomes they deliver to patients daily.
cons: Hospital administration  has many areas for improvement. The culture is very toxic. Specific cons include: 1. making employees pay to park 2. executive officers playing favoritism to more attractive female associates -- one associate with one year of experience out of undergrad became "director" of an entire service line literally overnight after talking with the then COO that "she was better than these tasks"... yet she had zero prior job experience or expertise in the domain...that seems fishy.  Sounds like a c-suite desire for eye candy to me. 3. office buildings spread out so far that you spend half your day (literally) going to different locations for meetings 4. employees are charged a considerable monthly fee for campus gym access, which makes zero sense given the substantial productivity benefit directly related to employee mental and physical health, not to mention engagement and association with colleagues and being on campus as well as it being a nominal cost center for the university. 4. duplicative projects/initiatives everywhere. I lost track of the number of projects and engagements that I either led or supported that were duplicated or repeated in some shape/form within 18 months. 5. The org is very siloed. There are at least 6-7 different quality/improvement/consulting teams and departments that do similar or identical work with many overlapping projects. This creates culture issues, hostile environments, and wasted effort. 6. "Overly most-wired" hospital. They pride themselves on being a most-wired hospital yet performance outcomes are average relative to the US measures. This is why the clinicians here have a higher than usual hatred for tech, b/c most of that implemented here is not necessary... it's a fix for a symptom, not the problem(s) themselves. 7.  Bureaucratic, "put-in-your-time-good-ol-boys" culture, opposite of a meritocracy. IF you're looking for a merit-based org with promotions based solely on performance, this is not the place. The promotion/advancement culture here is very much like a law firm, where someone with 25 years of experience automatically gets a position over someone with 21 years of experience, even if the other person is more qualified. Because apparently only years matter. I was told that my next promotion would be a while because others had 20+ years of experience. Mind you these "others" were part of departments and groups that were commonly under-performing and/or not delivering any value, lacked effort to grow/learn, and had limited breadth of industry knowledge of latest industry imperatives and success standards. Yet they were "more polished" for promotions, solely because they were well connected with other tenured senior leaders. Makes sense. And the results of such show... why the problems are chronic and cyclical, happening over again about ~18 months or sooner. My favorite icing on the cake was while riding over with one executive to a cross-campus meeting -- after not finding a front row parking spot she said that she guesses "that I'll just have to park on an upper floor with all the minions." I was floored. Very reflective of the culture. 8. Use it or lose it PTO structure. This is the worst structure for incentivizing employees to take vacation. While I totally understand the rationale from a financial standpoint (lowering the amount of carryover liability for unused PTO to next fiscal year/ tax year), many positions, namely clinicians, have inflexible PTO schedules, where employees can't take the PTO days even when they're expiring. Their requests are declined and they lose the PTO hours/days. 9. Limited recognition of your work; there was non-existent efforts to make employees feel valued and like our work mattered.  Often times it felt like the immensely high-value work I produced (with a great supporting cast) was irrelevant b/c decisions were already made by senior leadership based on their personal beliefs, as though our work was a formality for political reasons. 10. No exit interview… at all. Hence why these problems persist year after year… explain to me why has the CHRO Traci not been fired yet? Unacceptable.

job_title: Data Management Specialist in Clarksville, TN
pros: Vanderbilt was great at training me for the job I was going to be in. I worked with some great people as well. I also had an amazing manager who saw my potential and granted me a promotion fairly quickly. Plenty of room to grow when working for Vanderbilt.
cons: Having to pay to park was the biggest con. The pay is not that great either for the workload as well as my Bachelor's degree I had.

review_title: Great place to work if you can navigate the politics
pros: This medical center has a great reputation for a reason, its filled with a lot of talented people.  Its also poised for tremendous growth over the next few years.
cons: Whether due to the number of grants from the government or its connection to academia, this place is highly political and management top-heavy, which can lead to not enough worker bees.

job_title: Research Assistant II in Nashville, TN
pros: Flexible work place that did not require punching a clock.  Lenient schedules and ability to make major academic connections
cons: Work conducted in an academic research facility is not considered by industry.  The rate of pay is grossly under the national average and rate of promotion is at neuron growth speed.

review_title: Vanderbilt; a dynamic place to work.
pros: First rate tertiary care facility. Big on collaboration between MD and RN. RN opinions are valued by physicians. Unusual and interesting patient care challenges. When I get to go to conferences, I am able to participate at a level and to offer coherent opinions on topics that some of the physicians don't fully understand. It is humbling. Such a gift. Physicians are excellent and are extremely generous. It has been both a privilege and a pleasure to serve with them.  Comparatively low pay, but benefits are excellent (college tuition reimbursement for employee, spouse, 3 kids per employee, etc). Ongoing efforts to improve are paying off. Nursing capable of pulling it together enough to win awards. As long as they let me use what I know to take care of people and allow me to grow personally and professionally, I will continue to be a part of the Vandy family. So far, they haven't disappointed.
cons: Emphasis on incident reporting ostensibly for improvement has backfired. Collaborative atmosphere is becoming punitive mess. Needs to be a way to report positive things and it needs to be emphasized. Veritas has NEVER been presented on my unit without a sideways reference by management that no matter what the advertizing says, can be used punitively. Nursing continuing education for frontline nurses is sporadic. It's a really big place. Easy to get lost.

pros:
Tuition benefit for career advancement helped me complete MSN. My co-worker stays working for the benefit to be paid for her kid's collage tuition. 
I believe the safer nursing environment in terms of the quality care and safety than other hospitals in the area because of the magnet status awarded by ANCC.
cons:
No bonuses for more than 4 or 5 years. 
You have to pay a monthly parking fee as an employee if you drive to work which majority of us do!

pros:
The best part of working for Vanderbilt University Medical Center are the benefits!  They provide unparalleled health coverage for both individuals and family members.  They also provide 403b, the opportunity to invest in a group IRA account, and many citywide/internet-based discounts and other benefits!  

In addition, the management staff are very easy to approach and talk to, they take hours seriously, and hours that must be worked over one's scheduled shift usually come with a payment incentive!  

Vanderbilt University Medical Center also awards hard work with timely yearly raises, events for employees take place annually, and employees are also encouraged to pursue a healthier living arrangement including:  eating healthy, attending weight loss workshops, forming weight loss groups among peers, and weight loss competitions.  In addition, VUMC utilizes a lot of classes and instruction to encourage people to quit smoking and intaking other intoxicating substances.

Finally, another benefit for working for VUMC is the free transportation.  The bus system within the area is free to employees with an employee badge, and riding the bus (exclusively for work-related purposes) is covered by the VUMC!
cons:
Parking is a big issue with staff in general.  Though it is understandable considering the number of employees, many complain at having to pay to park.

Workload is another issue.  This issue I believe is a temporary issue, but speaking from a current time frame, workloads can become rather robust.  I'm sure in time with more employees joining the VUMC ranks, the workload will return to normal.

review_title: Great Benefits, but organization is too big
job_title: Senior Software Developer in Nashville, TN
pros: Great Benefits, good amount of time off, lots of great people, meaningful work.
cons: While combined with Vanderbilt University it was too big and moved too slowly. Job offers can take months to materialize. Right hand did not always know what the left hand was doing. Poor inter departmental collaboration. Pay was rather low for the Nashville area, but many of the benefits helped to make up for it (a little bit). Often overlooked great software developers because they did not have a 4-year degree.

pros: good retirement benefits discounts on movies and you build vacation time,and you get meal tickets if you work the holidays.
cons: I can not seem to get a job in my chosen field of computer networking. i have put in for  a computer job for over 12 times in 5 years and have never gotten it. you can get where you want to if you know someone in that hiring department. i bet even if i had even beyond my associates degree in computer networking ie a+ n+ or mcp levels they still would not hire me.

review_title: Should have left a long time ago
job_title: Technology Support Manager in Nashville, TN
pros: Decent benefits, Tuition reimbursement. Nice facilities, up to date decor. Good reputation and Vanderbilt looks good on a resume.
cons:
Vanderbilt does not care about its employees. Now we are getting outsourced. Pay is horrid. You have to pay to park there and we won't be able to use the tuition benefit because I will be replaced by the time my kids go to college. 
Most of the time the left hand doesn't know what the right hand is doing.
Weak middle management.

job_title: Certified Surgical Technologist II in Nashville, TN
pros: I used to work in the ED and left for several years--now working as a surgical tech.  Have always found the doctors to be incredibly respectful and collaborative with the rest of the staff, which fosters excellent learning opportunities on a regular basis.
cons: Management decision making very frenetic. Lays off staff one month, offers bonuses to recruit staff back 6 months later when there's a staffing crisis.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Nashville, TN
pros: Physically located close to all major medical research labs. Overall good facilities, and good program for postdoc career training and management. Lots of opportunities for collaboration. Generally good research resources, and good formal structure for postdoc training advancement.
cons: Benefits only offered to fellows and not trainees (on a training grant). No support for transitioning between the two, and tax situation for trainees is very complicated, to say the least.

pros: The people from Director down to coworkers are friendly and make you feel apart of the Vanderbilt family from the get go.  Great working atmosphere, and I would recommend working for this company.
cons: The only downside was the fact I had to relocate back to NC for family reasons.  Otherwise I would still be working for this great company.

pros: Environment of excellence. Very good benefits. Working at an institution that values questioning the processes and tries to implement those to the benefit of patients and staff.
cons: Nothing to do with VUMC, just dealing with the traffic to ultimately get to work. Would recommend more ways to make employees feel a part of such a large place.

job_title: Health IT Project Manager in Nashville, TN
pros: The team members within the Health IT Project Management team, working with the actual end users of the project outcome, team participation within the Vanderbilt community
cons: Project Management executive level was the worst in my 30 year career in project management. Micromanagement from immediate boss, lack of participation from her boss.  Lack of communication, fixation on following the "steps" versus practical application or reality of project, overall apathy regarding team members.

review_title: Vanderbilt is cutting front line staff to the detriment of patient care
job_title: STaff Registered Nurse in Nashville, TN
pros: Health benefits, retirement match, great staff to work with, work life balance
cons:
Letting the more experienced older nurses go to save a buck
Staff to patient ratios are poor which translates to unsafe work practices for nursing staff
Worrying from one day to the next who will be without a job due to "restructuring"

job_title: Clinical Translational Research Coordinator in Nashville, TN
pros: The job is easy and I've been given opportunities to learn some new skills.
cons:
Have to pay to park.
Waiting years to get a raise and only end up with a cost of living increase of 2% 
Some of the lowest paying jobs in research I've seen. Nashville is not a cheap area to live in and the salaries have not kept up.

pros: Very proud of the care and research going on at Vanderbilt.  These efforts make marketing the clinical services much easier.
cons: Refusal to set priorities make marketing very difficult.  Refusal to make decisions pushes difficult discussions down to manager level--which is not effective or fair.

pros: stable, collaborating with great people, an opportunity to change healthcare for the better, passionate people, saving lives, being a positive impact on the community, benefits are strong
cons: compensation is lower than other in the competition in the market, due to the size and bureaucracy of the organization at times it can be difficult to get things done. There is an unwritten rule of clinical history in a person's background needing to be present to achieve high-level success within the organization administrative.

review_title: Good education opportunities, job salaries/benefits getting lower all the time.
pros: Cutting edge medicine and care to patients; excellent reputation.
cons: Benefits are slowly being cut to off set decreased medicare/medicaid reimbursements; no pay raise in over 3 yrs; no longer feel my job is secure; physicians are not held to the same employee expectations that other staff are-- for example... being hateful & condescending.  If I am not allowed to exhibit those behaviors, then why are they??  Very frustrating.

pros: The experience of level 1 trauma
cons:
Pay for parking, which is  miles away.  
Annual evaluations are ridiculous. 
Attitude of staff is pretentious and very hard to fit in. Very clique’y.  
Break room has segregated tables, divided by service- there’s no overall team work atmosphere. 
You will walk 8 miles a day to get supplies unless you are assigned to a service. Management is never around to help.  
Security is more concerned with giving out parking tickets than maintaining your safety in parking garages.

pros: The learning framework for nurses cannot be beat. You are exposed to complex cases with lots of autonomy.
cons: The pay is the worst in the area. Lowest paying hospital across the board. Management doesn't want to hear the truth, only fluff answers. There are not many rooms for advancement and some units can be very high school like. Gossiping, intimidation, lies and betrayal.

pros: Demanding environment but lots of smart people and great support.  Great place to do your graduate studies.  Lots of journal clubs and seminar opportunities.
cons: Work life balance suffers, but I think that is the case at any graduate school.  Working 50 to 60 hours a week and at least one weekend day is the norm.

review_title: Very good experience, we were given a lot of autonomy and senior managers relied on everyone's input.
pros: We worked with cutting edge technology and were given access to multiple projects. I felt my work was valued and utilized for their research.
cons: I saw minimal impact to my work. I saw first hand that some of the politics of science can overshadow clear results of a study.

job_title: Manager, Applications Systems Analysis & Programming in Nashville, TN
pros:
Very good work life balance
Great benefits
Great people
Amazing mission focused on research, teaching, and patient care
Tremendous opportunity to learn
cons:
Lots of shifting direction & 'science projects' that go nowhere.
Commute is very hard from most places with good public schools.
Good raises only seem to go with promotions or threats to leave, and those can only happen so often.
Tries to compete with vendors by reinventing the wheel.

review_title: My nursing and physician colleges have been very respectful.
pros: My nursing and physician colleges have been very respectful. There is a good culture here, and plenty of opportunities for continuing education, as well as career growth.
cons: Salary is not as competitive as the surrounding hospitals and the process to petition for a $2.- is so absurd and exhaustive that it serves as a major barrier to otherwise deserving employees ( you need to submit a full application packet to a peer-review committee  to prove that you have earned your $2.00) .

pros: Great benefits. Wonderful patient population. Great training in New departments. Mostly friendly people to work with. Great work experience.
cons: They tend to be very hard on the employees that work really hard while not caring that other employees are sitting around not helping patients or anything.

review_title: Mostly a good place to work.
pros: Management says they want everyone to succeed.
cons: The recent round of layoffs occurred with no input from anyone who actually know what is going on at the levels they were laying people off and seemed to be based solely on factors like salary and benefits. It was also done with no warning and the workers were treated like they had done something wrong.

job_title: Registered Nurse IV in Nashville, TN
pros:
Prestigious hospital looks good on resume
Nursing Magnet status
rated #1 hospital in the nation for patient care
cons:
Upper management doesn't listen to staff even when they go to Unit Boards and ask specifically for staff input
certain specialty staff are not held to the CREDO while others are
Very difficult to make a lateral transfer within hospital 
Morale really stinks

review_title: The experience is just ok. There are so many departments, that I am honestly thinking of transferring out of the ED.
pros: The best thing about working for VUMC is the organization. They are very adamant about making sure things run smoothly.
cons: The challenges of working for VUMC is the money. They have not given substantial raises in years. They just recently gave a 2% raise in 2015, but before that it had been rumored 5 years since the last one.

review_title: Overall a good place to work, but lacks organization at many levels.
pros: Good benefits, good people in the trenches.  Some departments offer flexible work arrangements.  College tuition assistance program for children and dependents after 5 years.
cons: Lack of unified direction.  Leadership often sends people in multiple directions simultaneously without having an overall strategic goal.  Fragmented reporting structures lead to bureaucracy and fiefdoms.

pros: Academic Medical Center, always learning about new patient care treatment. Never the same day. Wonderful opportunity to help and interact with patients from all walks of life.
cons: The time off policies have become very restrictive, and over the past 3 to 4 years the atmosphere has changed from a employee supportive environment to one that is very punitive towards employees. Benefits have been decreased, no raises, and morale is very low.

review_title: Offers a variety of settings to work
job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Nashville, TN
pros:
The people that are your coworkers
In general the providers ( Doctors, Surgeons,etc) are very good at                  sharing/teaching 
Environment of learning
Large entity allows for unilateral moves to other departments/ jobs without switching employment
cons:
Pay
Changes implemented are created using a business agenda, not healthcare

pros: Vanderbilt has a good work environment along with a good work/life balance.  The organization is trying to be one of the best places to work.
cons: With the cutbacks of recent years, a lot has changed.  Opportunities for advancement are more limited and there are more politics.  Training, especially external training, is at a minimum.

pros: Plenty of opportunity to move around,  but not necessarily UP.
cons: I havent really experienced many opportunities for advancement and I definitely dont have any opportunities to make more money. As of right now we are terribly understaffed and over worked... But they are not hiring any new people in my area. We are required to be on call at least twice per 6 weeks, and those calls ALWAYS get called in. So mandatory overtime.

review_title: Health benefits make it hard to leave
job_title: Clinical Trial Associate in Nashville, TN
pros:
Good insurance benefits (disclaimer:  VHAN network got smaller this year. $20 specialist copay went up to $50 if not a Vanderbilt provider.)
Meal truck Wednesdays :)
cons:
*This was just my experience in clinic, which was a very busy outpatient clinic. Does not reflect the inpatient experience*
1. Pay is below average for the area.
2. Training is inadequate for inpatient setting
3. Nonperformers get less and easier tasks...smooth sailing for them.

pros:
Good job benefits like insurance and 401k. 
Learnt new and advanced research techniques.
cons:
Negative attitude of the people in the lab.
People gossip a lot and are not very proffessional.
No encouragement or appreciation for good work done
No transparency 
No good regular feedback

review_title: VUMC is a great employer. There is room for advancement and great benefits.
pros: The benefits offered are great. There are great discounts offered to VUMC employees when using VUMC health providers. The PTO time is also very generous, especially for exempt employees.
cons: The compensation is slightly lower than other companies in the area like HCA. This is mostly combated with the great benefits and PTO time. This company also tends to move at its own pace and change policies rather frequently.

pros: There are a lot of dedicated, loyal employees working at the Medical Center. The patients and the good work we know we are doing make it a good place to work.
cons: Some staff are underused and unappreciated. Not everyone is treated fairly or equally. Very top heavy. A great deal of duplication of functions between departments and non communication between those departments.

pros: Big Name to put on a resume, some of the most innovation healthcare implementation
cons: Due to recent austerity measures they have ceased to be the premier employer they once were and that justified being the lowest paying hospital in middle TN.  Further due to staffing reductions it is creating overload dangerous to patients and practitioners.  All of which is leading to a downward trend in the perception of the Vanderbilt brand in Middle TN.

pros: I left and came back to Vanderbilt. I was at Vanderbilt previously for 8 years. Left for 1 year and 8 mths and came back. This is such an exciting, cultural environment to work in. The grass is greener here at Vanderbilt.
cons: I think pay can be a little higher and everyone could start at the mid range if experienced

pros: Great benefits, medical, dental, vision, 5 weeks vacation a year starting out (assuming 3- 12 hr shifts)
cons: Very low pay, I started out at $11.50/hr, I think it might be $12.50/hr now.  Care partners (CNA) are the ones who do all the work. The RN's get paid double what we get and sit down most of the night just talking. If you are a CNA, go somewhere else, if you are a nurse and lazy, this place is perfect for you.

review_title: VUMC is going through a tough time financially right now
pros: Co-workers, learning resources, benefits, moving to a PTO system gives more flexibility
cons: Staff walking on eggshells because of wide spread layoffs

pros: Vanderbilt has good benefits and most of the other employees are highly educated, dedicated people that are interested in serving the community.
cons: Vanderbilt has recently undergone many culture changes that are difficult  adjustments.  It has become more like a for profit company in its concern for its employees.

review_title: I have enjoyed working with such a great team!!
pros: The people I work with. The patients sometimes as well I just love what I do. The fact they treat you like a person and not a number.
cons: The drive home. That's all I really would have to say. Not much i dont like about here.

review_title: On a mission to improve health outcomes
pros: The stated mission of VUMC is admirable and it's easy to feel like you're having a positive impact on the community of Nashville AND the general public - especially if you work in research.
cons: Giant bloated bureaucracy, the divorce from VU creates all sorts of silly hurdles and headaches.

review_title: Rewarding Work but Pay is Low
pros: It is rewarding to do work that helps people who are going through a challenging medical situation. Benefits are great. Working hours are very flexible, but this is unit-specific.
cons: The University does not pay very well. Could make more money in private industry.

review_title: A very educational experience at the enterprise level at a large healthcare organization
pros: Lots of opportunities to learn about MANY different facets to supporting IT in an enterprise healthcare environment. Good place to learn. You can see and experience many different types of leadership, teaching styles and tech levels.
cons: The recent restructuring of IT has lead to a situation where there appears to be no room for advancement.

review_title: I work at vanderbilt as a nurse for over 3 years
pros: Looks good on a resume(for now)
cons: Never get a pay raise, keep cutting benefits and staff. They expect us to work understaffed. High turnover rate due to all of this and instead of rehirin the position they just delete the position. Low morale don't even get a mug for nurses day. Sorry company to work for. Very disappointed. And now they just told us again they arre going to be cutting our pay and benefits again. OMG they already don't pay us for holidays we have to use our own time which they have drastically cut and are doing it again.

review_title: Great people, but low pay as expected for research.
pros: Good work/life balance, incredible people, fun place to work most of the time.  You gain a lot more knowledge working here than at other jobs.
cons: Low pay, sometimes not being challenged enough.  Sometimes I would go to work and not have anything to do for several hours, which gets boring eventually.

pros: Professional work environment, ability to learn new technologies, freedom to approach problems in different directions.
cons: Political backstabbing, non-transparent, employees used as pawns, lack of consistent discipline, no pay increase in 5 years.

review_title: These past two years have been full of fantastic learning opportunities.
pros: Fantastic place to learn and experience disease processes you won't see anywhere else. Bonus for being a teaching hospital, you can really grow as a nurse when you have to be sifting through orders put in by the new interns in July!
cons: We are chronically short staffed with little effort from management to relieve the added stressors. Raises are very minimal and barely enough to live in Nashville.

pros: The culture is strong with innovation and creativity. Flexible position for someone that has just begun to dabble with professionalism.
cons: At this time of review (couple days before (1/1/16) they're projects everywhere. Our jobs are currently be aligned and leadership is very unstable.

job_title: Materials Management Supervisor in Nashville, TN
pros: Good vacation policy, you get 3 weeks paid time off after 3 months, plus holidays. It increases one day each year for 10 years.
cons: They do not like to hire from within for upper management. They look outside first, before considering an internal candidate. If you want a good upper mgmt position, don't try to work your way up here, Try to get in close to the top.

pros: Cost of living is cheap plus as a vandy employee, one can use the metro buses for free (although a car is still necessary).
cons: Worked for a horrible professor who was eventually kicked out after 9 months due to ethics violations. Overall, Nashville is not cosmopolitan and is not racially diverse at all. Plus, the administration at the medical school is very biased towards only helping certain people but not all.

job_title: Senior Research Specialist in Nashville, TN
pros: Good benefits, great coworkers, and good work/life balance and scheduling flexibility
cons: For non-faculty or physicians, there is less professional development and/or promotion opportunities

review_title: Vanderbilt is a great place to work
job_title: Research Assistant I in Nashville, TN
pros:
This company is very good.  It is a well known and respected research institution with state of the art equipment and faculty that are at the forefront of their field.  
Excellent Benefits
Good work-life balance
Flexible hours
cons: None about the company, however each PI has pretty much absolute power within his own lab.  If you are hired into a lab with poor leadership you will have a bad experience.

job_title: Research Assistant II in Nashville, TN
pros: Research is very cooperative. The labs all work as a team. Almost everyone is friendly, and the campus is tobacco free. While you do have to pay to park, the fee can be taken out of your salary - which is a pro to a con.
cons: Starting salary is supposedly based on experience, but the university tends to start them out really low. Paying to park is also expensive.

pros: Great energy.  Surrounded by the next generation of scientific leaders.  Great benefits.
cons: Unqualified managers.  Upper management does not want to deal with incompetent middle managers so they just keep moving them around from clinic to clinic so they are not longer their program.

review_title: A hybrid of academia and business
pros: Good benefits, working with and around smart and motivated people, interesting problems and challenges, overall a good culture.
cons: Glass ceilings exist for non-faculty employees.  "Innovation" was a newly-added credo goal, but it is not rewarded or actively promoted.  Turf-wars and ownership silos (like anywhere else, really).

pros: Beautiful campus, amazing tuition benefits for children, great benefits package
cons: Incredible level of bureaucracy / red tape, extremely stagnant career and salary growth, depressing work environment due in large part to senior management.

job_title: Tech Support Manager in Nashville, TN
pros: They do things that are geared towards a blanace between home and work life and they understand that sometimes things just happen and they will be there to support you as long as your willing to step up and show that your willing to grow and take responceabilite for your actions and the choices in your life.
cons: I have yet to see any downsides to working here.

job_title: Physical Therapist Assistant in Nashville, TN
pros: Health benefits day 1. Great team work and training. Lots of diagnoses which makes it a great place to learn.
cons: Technically no paid holidays bc you are required to use your PTO if you don't work on the holiday. No shift differential on the weekends. Have to pay a monthly fee to park.

pros: Extremely collaborative within and across departments; great core facilities
cons: VU/VUMC split has made everything difficult, especially if you are paid off a training grant;  parking is expensive and inconvenient; not easy to be promoted quickly or have salary increased even if it's what you and your boss both want; compensation has not been adjusted to reflect ridiculous increase in cost of living in Nashville from 2010-2018

review_title: Great place to be a nurse
pros: Self-scheduling, high acuity patients and speciality care, providers are great to work with. Some/most of the units are recent renovations or new: really nice! Lots of nursing opportunity to find your niche as a RN. They did a pay adjustment this year, so that really helps as Vandy used to lag on nursing pay.
cons: Parking: you do have to pay to park. It's annoying but everyone does it.

job_title: Health Systems Database Analyst III in Nashville, TN
pros:
-Talented and knowledgeable staff
-Good benefits
-Stable
-Opportunity to learn many facets of healthcare 
-Well positioned within the Nashville community
cons: -Very large organization with many layers of management. Doctors have a lot of power outside their domain of expertise.

review_title: Business, Community, Social and Psychological Damage Done
pros: Service to the community via health care, research and education.
cons: No Performance based salary increases in 5 years. Continuous elimination of positions fosters daily concern over job security.  Contraction of benefits. Restricted communication from management. No career ladder nor mentor-ship. Cronyism. Emerging disparity between the University and the Medical Center. Departmental Silo environment.

job_title: Research Assistant I in Nashville, TN
pros: Great benefits. Looks good on resume. There are other job opportunities within vanderbilt. It is great experience if you are looking for a short term job.
cons: There have not been any raises in several years. The employees have a low overall morale. The work environment between doctors and nurses can be tense and hostile. Job security is also questionable with budget cuts always being expected.

pros: self schedule and paid time off
cons: work environment and lack of training and pay is terrible

review_title: Fine place to work if you want to work alone
pros: Great access to resources and equipment. Good pay and flexible working hours. Everything is centrally located unlike some large medical centers.
cons: Little guidance or help given to students. Often made to feel unimportant or ignored. Overall the environment does not foster growth.

job_title: Nurse Case Manager in Nashville, TN
pros: VUMC is a wonderful place to work. The culture promotes learning and growth, and this is an academic learning institution. The hospital is MAGNET accredited, and they really do support nurses.
cons: Salary is generally lower across the board for all job types. Due to financial constraints, they also recently changed their educational assistance program, which decreased the amount of tuition covered for ongoing education.

pros: Great benefits. Includes fitness facility with classes. They also offer nutritional assistance. I'm learning how to eat healthy and utilize the stairs at work for exercise.  The retirement tools are very beneficial as well.
cons: No pay raise in years due to the budget crisis. Extremely difficult to get in to a new position.

pros: Great health benefits, retirement package and their tuition benefits were very helpful to keep me challenged.
cons: Going through a lot of transitions in the past few years and the dust may not settle for quite a while as the University and Medical Center split.  There was much confusion over responsibility and accountability.

review_title: Not really worth it any more.
job_title: Bed Management Specialist in Nashville, TN
pros: Incredible amount of Vacation Time.
cons: Low pay. Below competitive to other facilities. Barely willing to give raises. Offering massive bonuses to outside temp employees vs supporting loyal employees.  The longer you are here, the more you are punished.  Benefits are being removed and/or restricted dramatically.

pros: Tuition benefits for children of employees.
cons:
Employee health care , dental, and pharmacy plans are not as good as they should be, considering they are a major health care provider. 

Although they have made considerable progress the last few years in expanding garages and valet services, parking is still an issue for patients and employees at VUMC.

pros: Great community and very supportive administrative staff. Faculty and researchers are very collaborative, and there is a great sense of belonging to a bigger project/research and health care community.
cons: Still trying to find that out.....so far, I would say like in many other places, the lack of possibilities for research staff and postdoctoral trainees to achieve more at their work. Also, lack of evaluation of own Faculty and how they support/not support their trainees/students.

job_title: Database Administrator Associate in Nashville, TN
pros: Friendly workplace. Supports you learn new skills and teaches you until you get the skills and knowledge that you need to work for your position.
cons: The team I worked didn't have a next-level position for me to go forward or get promoted but were pretty supportive when asked for an interdepartmental change or a change in the team when asked for the level up in the job

review_title: Mostly good experience, but management lacks majorly.
pros: It was a decent job to make ends meet until the job market opened back up. The work here was very easy and most people at Vanderbilt seemed to get along well.
cons: The area I worked in was very mismanaged. Communication lacks majorly and the pay is minimal.

job_title: Research Assistant I in Nash, TN
pros: They offer a good health benefit package, research environment is invigorating and all the departments are impressively correlated. Its truly like a family.
cons: The salary is not so good. Promotions and personal growth comes down to your boss.

job_title: IT Project Manager in Nashville, TN
pros: Good Salary. Good benefits. Country club atmosphere.
cons: Highly political. Forget advancement unless you have a degree from Vanderbilt. Can be fired at any time. There are the insiders and the outsiders. You will probably be an outsider. It's really just a big academic country club with a highly over-rated reputation and an enormous endowment. Not run like a business. More like one big research project.

pros: The best part about working at Vanderbilt is the strong sense of family and being a part of something. The benefits are good (gym membership, educational credits, health insurance, decent vacation).
cons: There have been some major cuts in sick time recently. The pay is low because the benefits are high.

review_title: Terrible working in my department pediatric ENT
pros: There are no positives to this job
cons: People look down on you if your badge ID doesn't say nurse, doctor or nurse practitioner. Doctors run over you and don't say sorry. Nobody acknowledges you. Medical assistants in my department are treated like slaves. After the taxes are taken out of your check you only make 600 a month. Great place for patients terrible work place management sucks.. Other employees complain about everything they cut from you and everything they promise but don't do.

review_title: VUMC is mostly a good place to work-like everywhere-depends on your immediate supervisor!
pros: Lots of opportunities for advancement or change. The benefits are good, the best by far being the tuition benefit, where they will pay a large percent of your childs college tuition.
cons: Terrible parking conditions (having to park far away). And having to pay to park. Getting lost in the shuffle.

pros: Collaborative atmosphere makes for great research environment. Great support for young researchers. Good benefits including health, subsidized daycare. Location is very convenient as well. Excellent IT division for clinical medicine
cons: Salaries aren't on high end considering Nashville isn't a cheap city anymore. Higher out of pocket healthcare costs than other places I've heard of; cost ~$2500 for labor and delivery charges for recent pregnancy at local hospital.

pros: The benefits are great.  The people are very nice.  The facilities are top notch.  The pay is great.  The location is great.
cons: The work can be hard and draining at times but not always.  The hours at night can be hard to work.

review_title: Not as bad as it seems
job_title: Associate Program Manager in Nashville, TN
pros: health insurance, good amount of vacation time
cons: Vandy wide HR doesn't get in a hurry for much, pay is not great, use or lose your vacation time, must use PTO for holidays, work from home opps minimal, traffic getting in to campus is awful

pros: Great benefits, looks good on a resume. The hours weren't full time which sucked pay-wise, but the work day was intense so it was good to have time off and on like that. They still gave us full-time benefits, too, which was nice.
cons:
Listen, working in a psych hospital is hard anywhere you go. I just hoped since it was Vanderbilt that it would be a better experience. Apparently not. 

I got paid $12 an hour, 32 hours a week and had to pay almost $50 a month for parking in *their* parking garage. I didn't even know my manager's name, and was also assigned to a unit where I explicitly said in my interview I wasn't comfortable working.That speaks for itself the culture of this place.

They talk big game about wanting to create a "healthy" & "ethical" work environment, but if you actually question things it does nothing but make people mad. There were multiple unethical things happening & I had no one to report to about it that would listen or do anything.

The model itself for the work I did was skewed & wasteful of the patient's time and money. Maybe if they had someone other than a military guy with a *business* degree running it, they'd be able to change things. 

Overall, it makes me mad that this is considered such a high quality facility yet it had such low standards of care in terms of regular, direct mental health support available to patients. They come here for mental health support, what's the point if their doctor is almost never there to talk to them or give them guidance on how to spend their time? A psych nurse is NOT remotely a therapist. 

Having patients sit & color or watch TV is not helpful. As an MHS I was essentially babysitting & I hated having my hands tied. I couldn't stay there if I wanted to be able to actually give a damn.

review_title: It's getting worse all the time
pros: Health insurance is at least reasonable.
cons:
- almost every unit is chronically under staffed. Instead of allowing employees to work overtime, they expect us to work short (almost an exact quote from my manager). 
- Day and night shift pays for parking. It goes up annually. Night shift has zero options for free parking. Day shift has one very inconvenient option for free parking. 
- Employees get an "occurence" for every absence, even with a doctor's note. They expect hospital employees to come to work with sick and immuno-compromised patients. No excuses. 
- Employees with longevity and good work history are treated no different from those with a poor company history. 
- Benefits to working at Vanderbilt are constantly being taken away. Health insurance keeps going up, tuition assistance is being taken away. 
- Hospital wide policies are constantly made that negatively impact some departments with no consideration to the individual needs of each department. 
- Nurses are treated considerably better than tech staff and have much less accountability than they should have. Techs will be fired before a nurse even when the nurse should have been responsible. 
- A lot of micromanagement from people running multiple departments that have no idea about the tasks and responsibilities of some of the departments they oversee. 
- Raises are minimal. Maybe 2% if you've been good. There are no raises based on merit. Doesn't even offset parking increases.
- The staff to patient ratios are poor. 
- Management does not take into consideration staff suggestions or input. 
- There is little opportunity to advance in this institution. 
- Profits are much more important to Vanderbilt than quality of care. 
- Campus is riddled with cockroaches and rats. 
- in the adult hospital there is only one cleaning person at night. Bathrooms and waiting areas are frequently dirty and littered. 
-The use of PTO is constantly having more and more restrictions added.

review_title: Great place to work but only if you're a new nurse.
pros: Great reputation in the community.
cons: They do not spend money on existing units, they only build more so as to make more money. If you're an older nurse, watch out. You make too much salary and they are looking for reasons to get rid of you. They lost $300 million in endowments due to the economy and they are looking for experienced nurses to get rid of.

review_title: life as a grad student mom
pros: Graduate school is a flexible environment, I find that students have the freedom to organize themselves around their personal life enough and they go at their own pace.
cons: Some departments are not so well organized for students to meet all the professors.

pros: Excellent people to work with, cutting edge research, great benefits
cons: Growth opportunities and focus is given to faculty members and research support staff has few opportunities to grow in spite of performance. Poor salary compared to other institutes and prevailing wage.

review_title: Beware! Vanderbilt feels you owe them for giving you a job.
pros: Vanderbilt looks great on a resume.
cons:
Terrible parking options for employees.
No tangible rewards for longevity with the company.
They change the rules ad lib and although MD's are not supposed to have the power of firing any staff employed with the hospital that is something that regularly occurs.

review_title: Great research assistant job as undergraduate student
pros: Great environment and supervisors. Accommodating and flexible of student schedules but I was still given responsibility as a student research assistant that made me feel involved and like i wasn't just doing busy work.
cons: Didn't have a set up program in place for student research assistants so I just got a hodge podge of work. Interesting, but inconsistent

job_title: Research Licensed Practical Nurse in Nashville, TN
pros: The pros of the company is that people respect the name Vanderbilt and that seem to carry a huge weight.
cons: The company charges its employees to park and the insurance is expensive if do not see a Vanderbilt physician.

pros: It was great experience to work at Vanderbilt medical center. Learned more during these 3 month than I did in 5 years on my previous job. Management is very approachable and easy to get along with.
cons: Like any hospital, this is a high stress environment, they are desperate for workers therefor tend to ask for individuals to work overtime.

review_title: Benefits decline again for 2020 with no warning!!!
pros: Excellent nurses to work with but many becoming disgruntled
cons: Lose benefits every year. Never allowed to take the entire amt of vac you accrue

review_title: Great Place to do biomedical research

cons: Living expense is higher than what I expected. The traffic is terrible during the rush ours. There are no straight road in Nashville. And whenever there is a rain, there is a flood.

review_title: Was like home away from home.
pros: Great place to work, great benefits, and great employees. The departments I worked with were great people.
cons:
They're having some financial issues and cutbacks everywhere.
Benefits are no longer what they used to be.
Forced to not get cost of living or merit raises several years.

review_title: Not sure what is asked for here.

cons: Rarely do they give raises that are more than just cost of living.  If you are considering going to work there negotiate for a larger salary on the front end.

job_title: Principal App Specialist in Nashville, TN
pros:
Flexible schedules
Learning opportunities
Great coworkers
cons:
Priorities are sometimes not well defined or agreed on
Frequent leadership changes
Too many middle managers and directors

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Nashville, TN

review_title: No Seniority Benefits for Nurses in the Clinical Staffing Resource Center

pros:

job_title: Research Analyst II in Nashville, TN

Really depends from team to team. My experience is positive.
Good hours, good benefits
Prestigious Institution, many NIH-related opportunities for the PIs and team, ready access to excellent healthcare and diverse patients
cons: Lack of transparency institution-wide, low salaries, plenty of red tape especially with HR, hard to work up

review_title: Vandy is a right of passage

Young fun nurses to work with.
Support with in my unit.

You are just a number to them.

On calls!!!

job_title: Research Assistant III in Nashville, TN
